turn.2: In 1942, "The Falcon Takes Over", a 65-minute film that was the third in the "Falcon" series about Michael Arlen's gentleman sleuth Gay Lawrence (played by George Sanders), used the plot of "Farewell, My Lovely".
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: In 1944, Dick Powell played the part of the hard-boiled detective, named Philip Marlowe this time, in a classic film noir release—alternatively entitled "Murder, My Sweet" (in the United States) and "Farewell, My Lovely" (in the UK)—two years before cinema-goers saw Humphrey Bogart as Philip Marlowe in "The Big Sleep" (1946).
turn.6: In 1975, Robert Mitchum starred in a remake of "Farewell, My Lovely".
turn.7: Was it ever released on audio?
turn.8: The novel was adapted on BBC Radio 4 by Bill Morrison, directed by John Tydeman and broadcast on 22 September 1988, starring Ed Bishop as Marlowe.
turn.9: Was that the only audio version ever released?
turn.10: BBC Radio 4, as part of its Classic Chandler series, also broadcast on 19 February 2011 a dramatic adaptation by Robin Brooks, with Toby Stephens as the hardboiled detective.
turn.12: It was adapted in a condensed form under the title of "Murder My Sweet" on Hollywood Star Time, broadcast on 8 June 1946, starring Dick Powell.
